alt_statements.statement: As a Puerto Rican-born U.S. citizen who can’t vote for president while living on the island, I think the Electoral College is fundamentally unfair and needs major reform. I’d support moving to a national popular vote so every citizen’s ballot counts equally, no matter their state or territory, and so candidates have to campaign for everyone’s support instead of just a few swing states.

As someone who immigrated here and takes citizenship and tradition seriously, I think we should keep the Electoral College but make a few reforms to improve fairness. I’d support changes like allocating electors by congressional district or proportional to the statewide vote, rather than winner-takes-all, so people in both big cities and small towns feel their votes matter. This keeps the balance between states and the whole country, while reducing the sense that some states are ignored.

As someone who believes deeply in equality and social justice, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot counts equally, regardless of where you live. Our current system makes some votes effectively “worth more” than others, which undermines both fairness and people’s faith in democracy. A direct popular vote, with strong protections for voting rights and access, would better reflect the will of the people and align with the values of a modern, diverse country.

At my age, I feel we should be very careful about changing something as fundamental as the Electoral College. It helps ensure that smaller and less-populated states still have a voice, instead of everything being decided by a few big cities. If there are reforms, they should focus on making the process more transparent and secure, not replacing it with a direct popular vote that could ignore the concerns of many communities.

I think the president should be picked by whoever gets the most votes from people all across the country, because it feels more fair if every person’s vote counts the same no matter what state they live in. The Electoral College seems confusing and kind of random, like someone could win even if most people didn’t vote for them, and that doesn’t match what I’m learning about everyone being equal.

As someone who spends her days immersed in data and evidence, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, or at least significantly reformed to better reflect the principle of “one person, one vote.” The current system effectively magnifies the voices of a few swing states while muting millions of voters elsewhere, which offends both my scientific sense of fairness and my belief in equal representation. A nationwide popular vote—with robust safeguards like automatic voter registration, secure paper trails, and nonpartisan administration—would align our electoral system more closely with how we evaluate outcomes in research: every data point (or voter) counted once, transparently and directly.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because every person’s ballot should count equally no matter what state they live in. As a young, progressive voter who cares about fairness and participation, it bothers me that candidates mostly focus on a few swing states while ignoring issues in places like my community. A popular vote system would push campaigns to speak to all Americans, including young people and working families, instead of just tailoring their message to a narrow group of states.

I don’t really understand the Electoral College, but I think it would be fair if everyone’s vote counted the same, no matter what state they live in. My parents tell me that in America everybody is supposed to have a voice, so I like the idea of just adding up all the votes and whoever gets the most wins.

As someone who believes in fairness and accountability, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every vote counts equally, whether you live in a swing state or not. Working in retail, I see every day how much people’s voices and choices matter, and it bothers me that a candidate can win the presidency while losing the popular vote. A direct popular vote would better reflect the will of the people and strengthen faith in our democracy.

The Electoral College should be preserved because it protects the voice of smaller and less populated states, prevents candidates from only focusing on big coastal cities, and reinforces the federal nature of our system. That said, I’d support some targeted reforms—like tightening rules on electors so they must vote according to their state’s results, and improving transparency in how votes are counted—to maintain public trust without throwing out a system that has provided stability for over two centuries.

I don’t totally get all the complicated parts of the Electoral College, but it seems kind of unfair that someone can win the presidency without getting the most votes from the people. I think we should switch to a national popular vote, so every person’s vote counts the same no matter what state they live in. That feels more honest and respectful to everyone, which is what we’re taught matters in school and at church.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime organizing in communities and believes deeply in every person’s dignity, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote. One person, one vote ought to mean the candidate with the most votes wins, no matter where those votes come from—whether it’s rural New Mexico or downtown Chicago. The current system makes some states and communities matter more than others, and that goes against the democratic values I came to this country believing in. If a full replacement isn’t politically possible yet, at minimum we should adopt reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact to move us closer to true majority rule.

At my age, having watched a lot of elections come and go, I still believe the Electoral College plays an important role in forcing candidates to pay attention to the whole country, not just the big coastal cities. That said, I’d be open to reforms like allocating electors by congressional district or using ranked-choice voting within states, so people feel their vote matters more without scrapping the system entirely. I worry that a straight national popular vote would weaken the voice of smaller states and rural communities that already feel overlooked.

Given how much I care about community and making sure everyone has a real voice, I think we should replace the Electoral College with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you live in. The current system makes a few swing states way too powerful and can put someone in the White House who didn’t actually win the most votes, which doesn’t feel democratic or fair. As a Democrat and a liberal, I want reforms that expand participation and representation, not ones that distort it.

At my age, I’ve seen that the Electoral College, while imperfect, plays an important role in making sure smaller and rural states like my own North Carolina still have a voice and aren’t steamrolled by a handful of big cities. I’d be open to modest reforms—like making the process more transparent or encouraging states to allocate electors by congressional district—but I don’t think we should scrap the system for a pure national popular vote that could deepen divisions and ignore the concerns of much of the country.

I don’t think we should get rid of the Electoral College, but I do think it could use some tightening up. It forces candidates to pay attention to different parts of the country instead of just big cities, which matters to folks like me who don’t have a lot of money or influence. I’d be okay with reforms like making states stick more closely to the popular vote within their own borders and increasing transparency in how electors are chosen, but I don’t want a pure national popular vote that could drown out smaller and more rural communities.

I don’t really understand all the complicated parts of the Electoral College, but I think it would be fair if everyone’s vote counted the same no matter what state they live in. Maybe we could change it so the president is picked just by who gets the most votes from all the people in the country, like how we vote for class president at school. That feels more equal and easier for kids like me to understand.

Given how divided our politics feel, I think it’s time to move away from the Electoral College toward a national popular vote, so that every ballot—whether cast in Kansas or California—counts equally. A system where the presidency goes to the candidate who wins the most votes nationwide would better reflect democratic values, reduce the outsized focus on a handful of swing states, and encourage candidates to speak to the entire country, not just strategic pockets of it.

At my age, having watched many elections come and go, I’ve come to believe the Electoral College no longer serves us well and should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot truly counts the same, no matter where they live. As a former teacher, I always stressed fairness and civic responsibility, and it troubles me that a candidate can win the presidency without winning the most votes. I’d support reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact or a constitutional amendment to ensure that the president is chosen directly by the people, reflecting the democratic ideals we claim to uphold.

The Electoral College feels outdated and undemocratic to me—every vote should count the same, no matter what state you live in. I’d like to see us move to a national popular vote, or at least require states to allocate their electors proportionally so candidates have to pay attention to more than just a handful of swing states. As a working mom trying to raise kids to believe in fairness and responsibility, it’s hard to defend a system where the person with fewer votes can still win the presidency.

I think the Electoral College should be kept, but maybe updated a bit so people feel their vote counts more, like using the district-based system they have in Maine and Nebraska. The current system helps make sure smaller, rural states like West Virginia still have a voice and aren’t totally steamrolled by big cities.

I think the Electoral College should be changed so that every person’s vote counts the same, no matter what state they live in, maybe through a national popular vote. It feels unfair that someone in a smaller or “swing” state has more impact than millions of people in bigger states, especially when those people include a lot of Black voters whose voices already get ignored in other ways.

As a conservative and a Republican, I believe the Electoral College remains an important safeguard that ensures smaller and less-populated states, like my home state of Colorado, still have a meaningful voice in choosing the president. Rather than abolishing it, I would support modest reforms to improve transparency and public trust—such as standardizing how states handle recounts and clarifying the role of electors—while preserving the basic structure that balances the interests of different regions in our large, diverse country.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts the same, no matter what state they live in. Working construction and seeing how different people get treated, it bugs me that a few “swing states” basically decide everything while millions of votes elsewhere don’t really matter. A direct popular vote would push candidates to focus on the whole country instead of just certain states, and that feels more fair and democratic to me.

Given how much I care about community voices being heard, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you live in. Working in outreach, I see how discouraged people get when they feel their vote is predetermined by “red” or “blue” state math, and that undercuts participation and trust. A direct popular vote would better reflect the will of the people and push candidates to engage with all communities, not just a handful of swing states.

To be honest, I don’t follow politics much, but I do believe that everyone’s voice should count the same, no matter where they live. If anything changes, I’d prefer a system where the president is chosen directly by the people’s total votes, so every ballot, including from immigrants who become citizens, matters equally. That seems more fair and more in line with the idea that hard-working people all have the same value.

As someone who grew up in France with a more direct relationship to national elections, the Electoral College seems outdated and at odds with the democratic principle of “one person, one vote.” I would support replacing it with a national popular vote, possibly with safeguards like ranked-choice voting to ensure broad support for the winner. This would make every vote count equally, regardless of state, and reduce the disproportionate influence of swing states.

As someone who works in information security and believes in systems that are transparent, resilient, and fair, I think the Electoral College needs serious reform. I’d prefer a national popular vote, or at least something like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact, so that every ballot is weighed equally no matter what state you live in. The current winner-take-all setup in most states distorts representation, discourages turnout in “safe” states, and doesn’t reflect the democratic values I care about as a liberal Democrat.

At my age, I tend to think the Electoral College has generally served the country well by forcing candidates to appeal to a broad range of states and regions, not just the big cities and the coasts. That said, I could support some modest reforms—like allocating electors by congressional district, or standardizing state rules—to make the process a bit fairer and more transparent without throwing out a system that helps preserve the voice of smaller and more rural states.

At my age, I’ve seen enough elections to know the Electoral College doesn’t always reflect what most Americans actually want. I’d like to see us move to a national popular vote, or at least reform the system so every vote counts equally no matter what state you live in. As a Democrat and a Christian, I believe in fairness and in every person’s voice mattering, and the current setup feels outdated and too easy to distort.

I don’t think we should get rid of the Electoral College, because it protects smaller and rural states like West Virginia from being completely ignored by big cities. That said, I’d be open to some reforms that make the process more transparent and ensure every legal vote is counted fairly, like tighter rules against ballot irregularities and clearer standards for recounts. I don’t want the presidency decided by a few coastal population centers or by whoever can stir up the biggest mob.

As someone who believes in making every vote count equally, I think we should move toward a national popular vote to replace the Electoral College. It doesn’t make sense that a few swing states get most of the attention while voters in solid red or blue states, like mine, feel sidelined. A popular vote would push candidates to campaign everywhere and focus on issues that affect people across the whole country, not just in a handful of battlegrounds.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every person’s vote really counts the same, no matter what state they’re in. It feels messed up that someone can win the presidency while losing the popular vote, and it makes a lot of people my age think the system is rigged or outdated. A direct vote would push candidates to care about all communities, not just swing states, and that seems way more fair and democratic to me.

As a naturalized citizen who chose this country and practices medicine in a diverse hospital, I believe every vote should carry the same weight, regardless of state lines. The Electoral College should be replaced with a direct national popular vote, so that the president is chosen by the clear will of the people, not by an antiquated compromise that can override the majority. Consistent with my humanitarian and Catholic values, a fairer system should amplify each person’s voice equally, especially those in marginalized communities whose needs are too often sidelined.

Working in local government, I see every day how important it is for people to feel their vote truly counts, so I lean toward replacing the Electoral College with a national popular vote or at least significantly reforming it. The current system can make some states feel ignored and others disproportionately powerful, which undermines trust in our institutions. A well-designed national popular vote, with strong protections for voting access and election security, would better reflect the will of the people while strengthening our sense of shared national community.

Given my belief in community health and interconnectedness, I think our political system should also reflect the will of people as directly as possible. I’d favor replacing the Electoral College with a national popular vote, so every ballot counts equally no matter what state you live in. Short of that, reforms like proportional allocation of electors or ranked-choice voting at the state level could at least reduce the distortion of winner-take-all rules and encourage candidates to engage more broadly with diverse communities.

As someone who works with data and evidence every day, I find the Electoral College increasingly hard to justify in a modern, diverse democracy. I would favor replacing it with a national popular vote, ensuring that every ballot carries equal weight regardless of state lines, coupled with strong protections for voting rights and access. If a full replacement is politically unattainable, I’d at least support reforms like proportional allocation of electors or ranked-choice voting at the state level to better reflect the actual preferences of voters. A system that so directly shapes national policy should be transparent, representative, and resistant to partisan manipulation.

The Electoral College is an anachronism that ought to be replaced with a national popular vote, so that every citizen’s ballot carries equal weight, whether cast in Minnesota or Mississippi. As someone who spent a lifetime teaching young artists to trust their own voices, I find it deeply troubling that our presidential elections can mute the will of the majority through arcane machinery and “battleground” cartography. If outright abolition proves politically impossible, we should at least adopt reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact and ranked-choice voting, to better reflect the rich, diverse chorus of Americans rather than a handful of swing states.

As a Black woman who’s seen how often our communities’ voices get sidelined, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you live in. The current system makes a handful of swing states far too powerful and can put a candidate in the White House who didn’t win the most votes, which feels fundamentally undemocratic. At 65, working in healthcare and focused on fairness and access, I want a voting system that reflects the will of the people directly, not one filtered through an outdated mechanism rooted in compromise with slavery-era interests.

I think the Electoral College should mostly be kept as it is, because it helps make sure smaller and less populated states like mine still have a real voice and aren’t drowned out by big cities on the coasts. If there’s any reform, I’d support things like tightening up election security, making voter ID standard across states, and making the process more transparent, rather than throwing out the whole system that’s worked for our country this long.

I think it’s time to move to a national popular vote, so that every person’s ballot truly counts the same no matter what state they live in. As someone who works in education and believes in teaching kids about fairness and equal voice, the Electoral College feels outdated and confusing, and it can undermine people’s faith that their vote matters. We should modernize the system so the candidate who gets the most votes from Americans actually becomes president, while also ensuring strong protections for voting rights in every community.

As a Democrat and someone who believes every person’s vote should carry equal weight, I think we should move toward a national popular vote for president, either by amending the Constitution or fully adopting the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact. The Electoral College makes some votes—especially in swing states—matter more than others, and that doesn’t sit right with my sense of fairness or my Catholic belief in the equal dignity of every person. At the very least, if we keep the Electoral College, we should require states to allocate electors proportionally rather than winner-take-all so that more voices are reflected in the final result.

I think the Electoral College is kind of confusing and doesn’t seem fair, because sometimes the person with the most votes from the people doesn’t become president. I’d rather have a system where every vote counts the same no matter what state you live in, so a popular vote sounds better to me. That way, kids like me growing up in places like Nebraska would know that when we’re old enough, our vote matters just as much as anyone else’s.

At my age, having watched so many elections come and go, I’ve grown uneasy with how the Electoral College can let the popular vote and the final result diverge. I’d like to see us move toward a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, whether it’s cast in Minnesota or elsewhere, while still making sure smaller and rural states like ours aren’t forgotten in campaigning. States banding together through reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact seems like a reasonable, gradual way to honor both majority rule and our federal system.

Given how divided this country is, I think it’s time to move away from the Electoral College and toward a national popular vote, where every person’s ballot counts the same no matter what state they live in. As someone who believes in fairness and accountability, it doesn’t sit right with me that a candidate can win the presidency while losing the popular vote, or that some “swing states” get all the attention while the rest of us are basically ignored. A straightforward popular vote would push candidates to campaign for every vote and speak to the whole country, not just a handful of battlegrounds.

I think the Electoral College still serves an important purpose by making sure smaller states like Utah have a real voice, instead of everything being decided by big cities on the coasts. That said, I’d support some reforms to make it work better, like requiring states to allocate electoral votes by congressional district or proportionally instead of winner-take-all. That would keep the balance between states while making individual votes feel like they matter more.

As a naturalized citizen who came from a country with a more straightforward national vote, I find the Electoral College outdated and at odds with the democratic principle that every vote should count equally. I’d support replacing it with a national popular vote, or at least reforming it—through measures like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact—to ensure the presidency reflects the will of the majority, not a handful of swing states.

I think the Electoral College should be kept, but it could use some adjustments so people feel their votes matter more, like encouraging states to split their electoral votes by district instead of winner-take-all. The system forces candidates to appeal to a wide range of states and regions, not just big cities, which protects folks in smaller and rural communities like mine from being ignored.

I believe the Electoral College should be preserved, because it protects the voice of smaller and more rural states like Missouri and keeps our elections from being dominated by big coastal cities. That said, I’d support modest reforms—like more transparency around how electors are chosen or stronger rules to prevent “faithless electors”—as long as the basic system that balances power among the states stays in place.

As someone who works in public education and believes deeply in civic equality, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot counts the same, no matter what state you live in. Our students are taught that we’re a democracy where each person’s voice matters, and our system should reflect that principle instead of giving disproportionate weight to a handful of swing states.

At this point in my life, I’ve seen too many elections where the person with fewer votes still walks away with the presidency, and that just doesn’t sit right with my sense of fairness or democracy. I think we should move to a national popular vote, or at least reform the Electoral College so that votes are allocated proportionally, instead of winner-take-all by state. Every citizen’s vote—Black, white, rich, poor, urban, rural—ought to carry the same weight, and the current system simply doesn’t deliver that.

I think the Electoral College should be kept, but we ought to tighten up how it works so folks trust the results more. It forces candidates to pay attention to smaller states like Maine instead of just big cities, and that helps keep the country balanced. We could look at reforms like making states follow a district-based system like Maine already does, so people feel their vote matters more without throwing out the whole system.

As a Christian, family-oriented Latino from California who leans Republican, I think we should keep the Electoral College but modernize it rather than scrap it. It forces candidates to pay attention to different regions and not just the biggest cities, which protects smaller and more rural communities, but I’d support reforms like allocating electors by congressional district or improving how states handle elections to make sure every legal vote is counted fairly and transparently.

As someone who cares a lot about language and how we frame democracy, I think the Electoral College is an outdated mechanism that distorts the plain meaning of “one person, one vote.” I’d support a national popular vote for president, or at least reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact, so every ballot is weighted equally no matter where you live. It bothers me that candidates focus on a handful of swing states while voters in solid red or blue states are effectively sidelined in what’s supposed to be a national decision.

I think the Electoral College should mostly be kept, because it makes sure smaller states like mine still matter and aren’t totally drowned out by big cities on the coasts. That said, I’d be open to some reforms—like making sure each state’s system is fair and transparent, and cracking down on any attempts to game the rules—so people trust that the results really reflect how the country voted.

As a naturalized citizen, I value the stability and balance the Electoral College provides, especially in making sure smaller and less populated states still matter in national elections. I don’t think it should be abolished, but I do support reforms that improve transparency, prevent faithless electors, and encourage candidates to reach out beyond a few big cities. For example, states could consider proportional allocation of electoral votes so rural and suburban voices, like families like mine, are represented more fairly without losing the federalist structure the Constitution set up.

As a liberal Christian and a Democrat, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot counts equally, no matter whether they live in a big city or a small rural town like many here in Arkansas. With our current system, candidates focus on a handful of “battleground” states, and people like me can feel like our votes don’t really matter. A direct popular vote would push politicians to earn support from all Americans, including lower‑income and disabled voters who are too often ignored.

I don’t think we should scrap the Electoral College outright, but it does need some reform to better reflect individual voters while still protecting smaller states’ voices. I’d favor a system like Maine and Nebraska’s—allocating electors by congressional district with a bonus for the statewide winner—so candidates have to compete more broadly instead of just chasing a few swing states.

I think the Electoral College should be changed so that every person’s vote for president counts the same, no matter what state they live in. When I read about elections, it feels unfair that some states get way more attention than others just because of how the system works. A national popular vote, or at least a system that awards electoral votes proportionally, seems more honest and better for teaching people that everyone’s voice matters equally.

I think the president should be picked by whoever gets the most votes from all the people, because that feels the most fair, like when we vote for class captain and whoever gets the most wins. The Electoral College seems confusing and makes it feel like some people’s votes count more just because of where they live, and that doesn’t seem right or honest.

My parents tell me that when people vote for president, sometimes the one with fewer votes can still win because of the Electoral College, and that seems confusing and unfair, even to me. I think we should move toward a system where every person’s vote counts the same no matter what state they live in, like a national popular vote. That sounds more like the “fairness” and “honesty” they say Jesus cares about, and it might help make sure everyone’s community, including mine, really matters.

I think the Electoral College should be reformed to a system that better reflects the actual popular vote, like a national popular vote with safeguards so smaller communities and rural areas aren’t totally ignored. As someone who cares about community and fairness, it bothers me that some votes count more just because of where you live, but I also get that we don’t want huge states or cities deciding everything alone. Maybe a proportional system in each state, instead of winner-take-all, would be a good step that keeps the basic structure but makes it more democratic.

Given my background in finance, I’m naturally drawn to systems that are transparent, efficient, and accountable, and the Electoral College just doesn’t meet that standard anymore. I’d support moving to a national popular vote with uniform voting standards across states so that every ballot carries equal weight, regardless of where you live. At a minimum, reforms like proportional allocation of electors or ranked-choice voting in presidential elections would make outcomes more representative and reduce the sense that some voters simply don’t matter.

I think the Electoral College should be preserved but updated, not scrapped. As a conservative and a legal immigrant, I value the way it forces candidates to pay attention to different states instead of just big cities, but I’d support reforms like allocating electors by congressional district or tightening state-level rules to prevent last-minute changes and confusion.

My mommy says the president should be the person that the most people pick, like when we all vote on which game to play at preschool. I think it should be more fair so every person’s vote counts the same, even where my family lives and on the reservation too. Maybe they can change the rules so it’s just everyone’s votes all together, and whoever gets the most wins.

I think it’s time to move to a national popular vote, so that every person’s ballot counts the same, whether you’re in Texas or a tiny swing state. The Electoral College makes it too easy for politicians to ignore whole communities like mine and just chase a few battleground states, and that doesn’t feel fair or democratic. If getting rid of it completely isn’t realistic right away, then at least states should award their electors proportionally so our votes aren’t wasted just because we’re in the minority in our state. A system that truly reflects the will of the people would strengthen our sense of community and trust in government.

Given how much technology and data we now have, the Electoral College feels like an outdated mechanism that distorts the principle of “one person, one vote.” I’d prefer a national popular vote with some form of ranked-choice voting, so every ballot directly shapes the outcome and third-party or independent candidates can participate without being spoilers. As someone who came to the U.S. from India and works in a data-driven field, the current system’s reliance on a handful of swing states looks both statistically inefficient and structurally unfair. Reforming it would make the system more representative and reduce the sense that some votes matter far more than others.

I think everyone’s vote should count the same no matter what state they live in, because that feels more fair, like when our teacher lets each kid have one turn. Maybe instead of the Electoral College, we could just add up all the people’s votes in the whole country and whoever gets the most wins. That way, people like my mom and our neighbors would all feel like their voices really matter.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because it makes more sense that every person’s vote counts the same no matter what state they live in. It feels unfair that candidates mostly care about “swing states” while people in other states get ignored, especially on issues like climate change and social justice that affect all of us. A popular vote system would push candidates to talk to more diverse communities and actually listen to young people’s concerns, not just the people in a few key states.

Given how data-driven our world is, it bothers me that the Electoral College can let someone win the presidency without winning the popular vote, which feels fundamentally undemocratic and out of step with the way we measure almost everything else. I’d support replacing it with a national popular vote, ideally with ranked-choice voting, so every ballot carries equal weight and candidates have to appeal to voters everywhere, not just in a handful of swing states.

As someone who became an American by choice and has spent a lifetime teaching students to think critically about democracy, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every citizen’s ballot carries equal weight. The current system can dilute the voices of Black voters, immigrants, and people in heavily partisan states, which runs counter to the ideal of “one person, one vote.” A modern, diverse country like ours should choose its president the way I grade my students—by counting each effort fairly and transparently, not through an outdated mechanism that favors a few swing states.

As someone who believes every person’s vote should count the same, I think we should move to a national popular vote for president and get rid of the Electoral College. It doesn’t feel right that a few swing states get all the attention while people like me in Kansas might as well be invisible. A popular vote would push candidates to care about all communities, including Black voters and folks with disabilities in smaller or more rural states.

As someone who teaches civics and believes deeply in democratic participation, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot counts equally, no matter where you live. The current system makes a handful of swing states far too powerful and discourages turnout in “safe” states like mine. A reform that directly elects the president by popular vote would better reflect the will of the people and strengthen the legitimacy of our elections.

The Electoral College is outdated and undermines the principle of one person, one vote, so I believe it should be replaced with a national popular vote where every ballot counts equally, no matter the state. As someone who values fairness, evidence, and democratic accountability, I’m uncomfortable with a system where a small number of swing states effectively decide the presidency. If a full constitutional amendment proves politically out of reach, I support reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact and proportional allocation of electors as interim steps toward a more representative system.

I’ve never been entirely comfortable with the Electoral College, especially after seeing candidates win the presidency while losing the popular vote. I’d support a system where the national popular vote actually decides the winner, or at least reforms like proportional allocation of electors by state so people’s votes feel like they count more equally. That said, I do think smaller states deserve some protection, so any change should make sure they’re not completely drowned out by the big cities.

Given the size and diversity of our country, I believe the Electoral College should be preserved but modernized, not abolished. We should keep the state-based system that protects smaller states and prevents candidates from focusing only on big cities, but I’d support reforms like allocating electors by congressional district or requiring states to follow uniform rules to make outcomes more representative and transparent.

As someone who believes in hard work and fairness, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every person’s vote counts equally, no matter what state they live in. Right now, candidates focus mostly on a few swing states, and that leaves a lot of communities like mine feeling ignored, even though we’re working, paying taxes, and raising families. A popular vote system would push politicians to pay attention to all people—especially working-class and minority communities—because every single vote would matter the same.

I think we should keep the Electoral College, but modernize it rather than scrap it. It forces candidates to build broad, nationwide coalitions instead of just pandering to big coastal cities, which matters for states like Massachusetts that already lean heavily one way. I’d be open to modest reforms like allocating electoral votes by congressional district or tightening rules around faithless electors, but not to a pure national popular vote that could sideline smaller or less populous states.

I think the Electoral College should mostly stay, because it protects smaller and rural states like mine from being totally ignored by big cities on the coasts. That said, I’d be open to states using a system like Maine and Nebraska where electoral votes are split by congressional district, so folks feel like their vote matters even if their state leans heavily one way.

I believe the Electoral College should be preserved, because it protects the voice of smaller and less populated states like many across the heartland, instead of letting only big coastal cities decide everything. If anything, we should focus on tightening election integrity—like consistent voter ID and clear rules in every state—rather than overhauling a system that has helped keep our republic balanced for over two centuries.

As a conservative and a Republican, I believe the Electoral College remains an important safeguard that ensures smaller and less-populated states still have a voice in choosing our president, rather than letting only big cities and coastal states decide. I’d support modest reforms to increase transparency and strengthen election integrity in each state, but I do not think we should abandon or fundamentally alter the Electoral College system.

As someone who became a U.S. citizen by choice and believes deeply in democracy, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts equally, no matter what state they live in. It doesn’t feel fair that a few swing states decide the outcome while millions of votes elsewhere are essentially discounted. A direct popular vote would better reflect the will of the people, especially younger, diverse, working-class communities like mine who are often underrepresented in national politics.

I think the president should be chosen by whoever gets the most votes from people all over the country, because that feels the most fair, like when we vote for class reps at school. The Electoral College seems confusing and can make some people’s votes matter less just because of where they live, which doesn’t seem right. If we changed it so every vote counts the same, I think more people would trust the system and care about voting.

I think the Electoral College still serves an important purpose in protecting the voice of smaller and more rural states, so I wouldn’t support abolishing it. That said, I’d be open to some reforms—like requiring states to allocate electors by congressional district instead of winner-take-all—so that people’s votes feel like they matter more no matter where they live.

As a naturalized citizen who worked hard to build a small cleaning business, I believe the Electoral College should be kept but updated, not eliminated. It protects the voice of smaller states and people outside the big cities, but I would support reforms like allocating electoral votes by congressional district or requiring states to follow clearer, uniform rules so elections feel more fair and transparent.

I believe the Electoral College should be preserved because it protects the voice of smaller and more rural states like Indiana, so that big coastal cities don’t decide every election on their own. If there are reforms, they should focus on improving transparency and integrity in how electors are chosen and votes are counted, not on eliminating a system that helps keep our republic balanced and accountable.

As someone who believes in our Constitution and the importance of giving smaller states a real voice, I’d be very cautious about getting rid of the Electoral College altogether. I would support modest reforms—like ensuring more transparency in how electors are chosen or considering proportional allocation of electoral votes within states—while still preserving the basic system that protects us from elections being decided only by big cities and coastal states.

I believe the Electoral College should be preserved, because it protects smaller and rural states like the ones I’ve lived in from being completely overlooked by big cities and the coasts. I would support some modest reforms to make the process more transparent and secure, but I don’t want a pure national popular vote where places like Pennsylvania lose their influence and the founding structure of our elections is thrown out.

I believe the Electoral College should be preserved but modernized, not scrapped. It forces candidates to build broad, nationwide coalitions instead of just appealing to a few big coastal cities, which helps protect the voice of states like Ohio. That said, I’d support practical reforms like improving how electors are chosen, increasing transparency, and exploring state-level changes such as proportional allocation of electors to better reflect voters’ choices without undermining the constitutional balance.

The Electoral College feels outdated and undemocratic to me; the person who wins the most votes nationwide should be the president, full stop. I’d support replacing it with a national popular vote, paired with strong protections for voting rights so every community—urban, suburban, and rural—has equal access to the ballot. As someone raising kids and working in healthcare, I want a system where every vote counts the same, no matter what state you live in.
